sp.p: He is fast enough I hope now, if I hold him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
You must not do so though, now I consider
Better what it is.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
Do not consider Angilo,
For I must do it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
No I will kill thee first.
I love thee so well that the worms shall have thee
Before this woman, friend.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: I was your counsel.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
As I was a knave,
Not as I loved thee.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
All this is lost upon me Angilo,
For I must have her: I will marry ye
When you please; pray look better on me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Nay then no more friend; farewell Iulio,
I have so much discretion left me yet
To know, and tell thee thou art miserable.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Stay thou art more than she, and now I find it.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Is he so?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: No, I will see thee starved first.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Friend.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Fly her as I do, Iulio, she is a witch.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Beat me away then, I shall grow here still else.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
That were the way to have me grow there with thee
Farewell for ever.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
Stay, I am uncharmed,
Farewell thou cursed house, from this hour be
More hated of me than a Leprosy.

sp.speaker: Lelia.
sp.p:
Both gon? a plague upon them both,
Am I deceived again? O I would rail
And follow them; but I fear the spite of people,
Till I have emptied all my gall; the next
I seize upon, shall pay their follies
To the last penny; This will work me worse
He that comes next, by heaven shall feele their curse.

div2.stage: Enter Iacamo at one doore Fabritio at another.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
O ye are a sweet youth, so uncivilly
To rail and run away?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
O are you there Sir?
I am glad I have found ye, you have not now your Ladies
To show your wit before.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Thou would not, would thou?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
What a sweet youth I am, as you have made me,
You shall know presently.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Put up your sword
I have seen it often, it is a Fox.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
It is so,
And you shall feele it too; will you dispatch Sir?
And leave your mirth out? or I shall take occasion
To beat ye, and disgrace you too.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Well since, there is no other way to deal with you
Let us see your sword, I am sure you scorn all odds,
I will fight with you -

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: How now?

div2.stage: (they measure, and Fab: gets his Sword.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Nay stand out,
Or by this light I will make ye.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
This is scurvy
And out of fear done.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
No Sir out of judgment,
For he that deals with thee, thou art grown so boisterous
Must have more wits, or more lives than another,
Or always be in Armour, or enchanted;
Or he is miserable.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Your end of this Sir?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
My end is only mirth to laugh at thee,
Which now I will do in safety; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: 'sheart? then I am grown ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Thou art,
And wilt be shortly sport for little children,
If thou continuest this rude stubbornness.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O God, for anything that had an edge?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Fie, what a shame it is,
To have a rubber show his teeth?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Why dost thou laugh at the thou wretched fellow?
Speak with a pox; and look ye render me
Just such a reason -

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I shall die with laughing.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
As no man can find fault with: I shall have
Another Sword; I shall ye fleeting puppy.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Does not this testiness show finely in thee?
Once shore take heed of children, if they find thee
They will break up school, to bear thee company,
Thou wilt be such a pastime, and hoot at thee:
And call thee bloody bones, and Spade, and Spitfire,
And Gaffer Madman; and go by Ieronimo,
And will with wisp and come aloft, and crack rope,
And old Saint Dennis with the dudgeon Codpiece:
And twenty such names.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No I think they will not.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Yes but they will: and Nurses still their children
Only with thee, and here take him Iacomo.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Gods precious, That I were but over thee
One Steeple height: I would fall and break thy neck.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
This is the reason I laugh at thee,
And while thou art thus, will do: tell me one thing.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
I wonder how thou durst thus question me,
Prithee restore my Sword.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Tell me but one thing,
And it may be I will: Nay Sir; keep out

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Well I will be your fool now, speak your mind Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Art thou not breeding Teeth?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: How? Teeth?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Yes Teeth, thou wouldst not be so froward else.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Teeth?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Come, it will make thee
A little rheumatic, but that is all one,
We will have a Bib, for spoiling of thy doubles;
And a fringed Muckender, hang at thy girdle,
I will be thy Nurse, and get a Coral for thee:
And a fine Ring of Bells.

sp.speaker: Jac.
Fab.
sp.p:
Now I love ye,
There, take your Sword, continue so: I dare not
Stay now to try your patience, Soon I will meet ye,
And as you love your honours, and your state,
Redeem yourself well to the Gentlewoman,
Farewell till soon.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Well I shall think of this.

div2.stage: Enter Host, Piso, and Boy with a glasse of wine.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Nothing in the world but a dried Tongue or two -

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Taste him and tell me.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
Is a valiant wine,
This must be he mine Host.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
This shall be Ipse,
O he is a devilish bitten wine, a Tyrant;
Where he lays hold Sir, This is he that scorns
Small Beer should quench him, or a foolish Caudle
Bring him to bed; no if he flinch I will shame him,
And draw him out to mull amongst old Midwives.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
There is a Soldier, I would have thee better
Above the rest, because he thinks there is no man
Can give him drink enough.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What kind of man?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p:
That thou mayst know him perfectly, he is one
Of a left-handed making, a lank thing,
As if his belly were taken up with straw,
To hunt a match.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Has he no beard to show him?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
Faith but a little; yet enough to note him,
Which grows in parcels here, and there a remnant:
And that thou mayst not miss him, he is one
That wears his fore-head in a velvet scabbard.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
That note is enough, he is mine, I will fuddle him
Or lie in the sudds; you will be here too?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Yes, till soon, farewell and bear up.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
If I do not,
Say I am recreant, I will get things ready.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: It is strange thou shouldst be thus, with thy discretion

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I am sure I am so.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: I am well you see.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Keep yourself warm then, and go home, and sleep,
And pray to God thou mayst continue so;
Would I had gon to the Devil of an arrant,
When I was made a fool to see her: Leave me
I am not fit for conversation.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Why, thou art worse than I was.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Therefore leave me,
The nature of my sickness is not eased
By company, or counsel, I am mad,
And if you follow me with questions
Shall show myself so.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: This is more than error.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Pray be content, that you have made me thus,
And do not wonder at me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
Let me know, but what you mean to do and I am gon
I would be loath to leave you thus else.

sp.speaker: Ang.
Iul.
sp.p: I would not leave you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You must and shall.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
I will then: would yon woman
Had been ten fathom under ground, when first
I saw her eyes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Yet she had been dangerous,
For to some wealthy Rock of precious stone,
Or mine of gold as tempting, her fair body
Might have been turned; which once found out by labour
And brought to use, having her spells within it,
Might have corrupted States, and ruined Kingdoms
Which had been fearful (Friend) Go, when I see thee
Next, I will be as thou art, or no more.
Pray do not follow me, you will make me angry.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Heaven grant you may be right again.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Score gallon of Sack, and a pint of Olives to the Unicorn.
Why drawer?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A non, a non.

sp.speaker: Another boy.
sp.p: Look into the Nags head there.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.p:
Score a quart of Claret to the Bar,
And a pound of Sausages into the flower-pot.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: The Devil is in their throats, anon, anon.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p:
Mull a pint of Sack there for the women in the
Flower-de-luce, and put in ginger enough, they belch like
pot guns,
And Robbin fetch Tobacco for the Peacock, they will not be
Drunk till midnight else: how now how does my Master.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.p: Faith he lies drawing on a pace.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.p: That is an ill sign.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.p: And fumbles with the pots too.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.p: Then there is no way but one with him.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.p:
All the rest,
Except the Captain are in Limbo patrum,
Where they lie sod in sack.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.p: Does he bear up still.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.p:
Afore the wind still, with his lights up bravely
All he takes in I think he turns to Juleps,
Or has a world of Storage in his belly,
The rest look all like fire-drakes, and lie scattered
Like rushes round about the room. My Master
Is now the lovingest man; I think above ground,

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.p: Would he were always drunk then.
Drawer.

sp.speaker: 2. B.
sp.p: Anon, anon Sir,

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.p:
And swears I shall be free tomorrow, and so weeps
And calls upon my Mistress.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.p: Then he is right.

sp.speaker: 1. B.
sp.p:
And swears the Captain must lie this night with her
And bad me break it to her with discretion,
That he may leave an issue after him:
Able to entertain a dutch Ambassador,
And tells him feelingly how sweet she is,
And how he stole her from her friends in the Country;
And brought her up disguised with the Carriers,
And was nine nights bereaving her her maidenhead,
And the tenth got a drawer, here they come.
Anon, anon, speak to the Tiger, Peter.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: There is my Bells boys, my silver Bell.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
Would he were hanged
As high as I could ring him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Captain.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Ho Boy.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Robin, sufficient single Beer, as cold as crystal,
Quench Robin, quench.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.p: I am gon Sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Shall we bear up still? Captain how I love thee?
Sweet Captain let me kiss thee, by this hand
I love thee next to Malmsey in a morning,
Of things transitory.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I love thee too, as far as I can love a fat man.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Dost thou Captain?
Sweetly? and heartily?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: With all my heart Boy.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Then welcome death, come close mine eyes sweet Captain
Thou shalt have all.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What shall your wife have then?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Why she shall have besides my blessing, and a silver spoon
Enough to keep her stirring in the world,
Three little Children, one of them was mine
Upon my conscience, the other two are Pagans.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
It were good she had a little foolish money,
To rub the time away with.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Not a rag,
Not a Denier, no let her spin in Gods name:
And raise her house again,

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Thou shalt not die though,
Boy see your Master safe delivered,
He is ready to lie in.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: God night.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
God morrow,
Drink tell the Cow come home, it is all paid boys.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: A pox of Sack.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Marry God bless my Buts, Sack is a jewel,
It is comfortable Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
More Beer boy.
Very sufficient single Beer.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Here Sir.
How is it Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: But even so, so.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Go before finely Robin, and prepare
My wife, bid her be right and straight, I come boy
And Sith, if they quarrel let them use,
Their own discretions, by all means, and stir not,
And he that is killed shall be as sweetly buried;
Captain, adieu, adieu sweet bully Captain,
One kiss before I die, one kiss.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Farewell Boy.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: All my sweet boys farewell.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Go sleep, you are drunk.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Come Gentlemen, I will see you at your Lodging,
You look not lustily, a quart more.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No Boy.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Get us a Torch.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It is day Sir.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: That is all one.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Are not those the stars, thou scurvy Boy?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Is not Charle-waine there, tell me that, there?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Yes;
I have paid them truly: do not vex him Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
Confess it Boy, or as I live I will beat
Midnight into thy brains.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I do confess it.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Then live, and draw more small Beer presently.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Come Boys, let us hug together, and be loving,
And sing, and do brave things cheerily my hearts,
A pox a being sad; now, could I fly
And turn the world about upon my finger,
Come ye shall love me, I am an honest fellow:
Hang care and fortune, we are friends.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No Captain.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Do not you love me? I love you too dearly.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
No by no means; you are a fighting Captain,
And kill up such poor people as we are, by the dozens.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: As they kill flies with Fox-tails, Captain.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Methinks now as I stand, the Captain shows,
To be a very merciful young man.
(And prithee Piso, let me have thy opinion)

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
Then he shall have mercy, that merciful is,
Or all the Painters are Apocrypha.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I am glad you have your wits yet, will ye go?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: You had best say we are drunk.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Ye are.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Ye lie.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: You are Rascals, drunken rascals.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: It is sufficient.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
And now I will tell you why, before I beat ye,
You have been tampering any time these three days,
Thus to disgrace me.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: That is a lie too.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Well Sir,
Yet I thank God I have turned your points on you,
For which I will spare ye somewhat, half a beating.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
I will make you fart fire Captain, by this hand,
And ye provoke, do not provoke I would with you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: How do you like this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sure I am enchanted.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Stay till I draw.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Despatch then, I am angry.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: And thou shalt see how suddenly I will kill thee.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Thou darest not draw, ye cold, tame, mangy Cowards
Ye drunken Rogues, can nothing make you valiant?
Not wine, nor beating?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
If this way be suffered
It is very well.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Go there is your way, go and sleep:
I have pity on you, you shall have the rest
Tomorrow when we meet.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
Come Lodowick,
He is monstrous drunk now, there is no talking with him.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
I am so, when I am sober, I will do more.
Boy where is mine Host?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He is on his bed asleep Sir.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Let him alone then: Now am I high proof
For my action, now could I fight bravely,
And charge into a wild fire; or I could love
Any man living now, or any woman,
Or indeed any creature that loves Sack
Extremely, monstrously; I am so loving,
Just at this instant, that I might be brought
I feele it, with a little labour, now to talk
With a justice of peace, that to my nature
I hate next an ill Sword: I will do
Some strange brave thing now, and I have it here:
Pray God the air keep out; I feele it buzzing.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
She loves him too much, that is the plain truth Fredrick
For which if I might be believed, I think her
A strange forgetter of herself; there is Iulio,
Or twenty more -

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
In your eye I believe you,
But credit me the Captain is a man:
Lay but his rough affections by, as worthy.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
So is a resty Jade, a horse of service,
If he would leave his nature, give me one
By your leave Sir to make a husband of
Not to be weaned, when I should marry him;
Methinks a man is misery enough,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
You are too bitter,
I would not have him worse.
Yet I shall see you hampered one day Lady,
I do not doubt it, for this heresy

sp.speaker: Clor.
Fra.
sp.p:
Does it so?
I am sure it fits thee to be ever talking,
And nothing to the purpose, take up quickly;
Thy wit will founder of all four else wench,
I thou holdest this pace; take up when I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Before your Brother fly?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I can endure it.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
Here is Raw-head come again; Lord how he looks?
Pray God we scape with broken pates.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
Were I he,
Thou shouldst not want thy wish, he has been drinking
Has he not Fredrick?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes but do not find it.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Peace and let us hear his wisdom.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You will mad him.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I am somewhat bold, but that is all one.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: A short and pithy saying of a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
As I live
Thou art a strange mad wench.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: To make a parson.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ladies I mean to kiss ye

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
How he wipes his mouth like a young Preacher;
We shall have it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
In order as you lie before me; first
I will begin with you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: With me Sir?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Yes
If you will promise me to kiss in ease.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I care not if I venture.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
I will kiss according to mine own inventions
As I shall see cause; sweetly I would wish you,
I love ye.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Do you Sir?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Yes indeed do I,
Would I could tell you how.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I would you would Sir.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
I would to God I could, but it is sufficient,
I love you with my heart.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Alas poor heart.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
And I am sorry; but we will talk of that,
Hereafter if it please God.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Even when you will Sir.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: He is dismal drunk, would he were muzzled.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
You
I take it are the next.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Go to him fool.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Not I, he will bite me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: When wit? when?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Good Captain.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Nay, and you play bo-peep; I will have, no mercy
But catch as catch may.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nay, I will not defend ye.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
Good Captain do not hurt me, I am sorry
That ever I angered ye.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
I will chew you for it
By this hand wit, unless you kiss discreetly.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: No more Sir.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Yes a little more sweet wit,
One taste more of your office: go thy ways
With thy small kettle Drums; upon my conscience
Thou art the best, that ever man laid his leg over.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
He smells just like a Cellar,
Fie upon him.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Sweet Lady now to you.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: For loves sake kiss him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I shall not keep my countenance.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Try prithee.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Pray be not coy sweet woman, for I will kiss ye,
I am blunt
But you must pardon me.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: O God my sides.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Why ha, ha, ha? why laugh?
Why all this noise sweet Ladies?

sp.speaker: Clor.
Fred.
sp.p:
Where were thine eyes
To take me for a woman, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Who art thou, art thou mortal?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am Fredrick

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Then Fredrick is an Ass,
A scurvy Fredrick to laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Sweet Captain.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
A way woman;
Go stitch and serve God, I despise thee woman,
And Fredrick shall be beaten; 'sblood ye Rogue
Have you none else to make your puppies of, but me?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p:
I prithee be more patient
There is no hurt done.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: 'sblood but there shall be, Scab.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Help, help for loves sake.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Who is within there?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: So now you have made a fair hand.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You have killed me -

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Call in some Officers, and stay the Captain.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: You shall not need.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: This is your drunkenness.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
O me unhappy Brother, Fredrick,
Look but upon me, do not part so from me,
Set him a little higher he is dead.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: O villain, villain.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: How now what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: O Sir my Brother! o my dearest Brother!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: This drunken trough has killed him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Killed him?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
Yes.
For heaven God sake hang him quickly, he will do
Every day such a murder else. there is nothing
But a strong Gallows that can make him quiet,
I find it in his nature too late.

sp.speaker: Fabr.
sp.p:
Pray be quiet,
Let me come to him.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Some go for a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
O what a wretched woman has he made me!
Let me alone good Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
To what a fortune,
Hast thou reserved thy life.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Never entreat me, for I will not know thee,
Nor utter one word for thee, unless it be
To have thee hanged; for God sake be more temperate.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I have a sword still, and I am a villain.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: etcetera. Hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
Away with him for heavens sake
He is too desperate for our enduring.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Come, you shall sleep, come strive not
I will have it so, here take him to his lodging, and
See him laid before you part.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: We will Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Never wonder, I am living yet, and well,
I thank you sister for your grief, pray keep it
Till I am fitter for it.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Do you live Sir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Yes, but it was time to counterfeit, he was grown
To such a madness in his wine.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
It was well Sir,
You had that good respect unto his temper,
That no worse followed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
If I had stood him, certain one of us must have perished,
How now Franke?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Beshrew my heart I tremble like an aspen.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Let him come here no more for heavens sake
Unless he be in chains.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
I would fain see him
After he has slept, Fabritio, but to try
How he will be; chide him, and bring him back.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: You will never leave till you be worried with him.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
Come brother, we will walk in, and laugh a little.
To get this Fever off me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Hang him squib,
Now could I grind him into priming powder.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Pray will you leave your fooling?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Come, all friends.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
Thou art enough to make an age of men so,
Thou art so cross and peevish.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
I will chide him,
And if he be not graceless, make him cry for it.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I would go a mile (to see him cry) in slippers
He would look so like a whey cheese;

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Would we might see him once more.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
If you dare
Venture a second trial of his temper
I make no doubt to bring him.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
No good Franke
Let him alone, I see his vain lies only
For falling out at Wakes and Bear-baitings,
That may express him sturdy.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Now indeed
You are too sharp sweet sister, for unless
It be this sin, which is enough to drown him,
I mean this sourness, he is as brave a fellow,
As forward, and as understanding else
As any He that lives.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
I do believe you,
And good Sir when you see him, if we have
Distasted his opinion any way,
Make peace again.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I will: I will leave ye Ladies.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Take heed you had best, he has sworn to pay you else.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I warrant you, I have been often threatened.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
When he comes next, I will have the cough or toothache,
Or something that shall make me keep my chamber,
I love him so well.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Would you would keep your tongue.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
I cannot keep from this ungodly woman,
This Lelia, whom I know too, yet am caught,
Her looks are nothing like her; would her faults
Were all in Paris print upon her face,
Cum Privilegio, to use them still.
I would write an Epistle before it, on the inside of her masque
And dedicate it to the whore of Babilon, with a preface upon
Her nose to the gentle Reader; and they should be to be fold
At the sign of the Whores head in the pottage pot, in what
Street you please: But all this helps not me; I
Am made to be thus catched, past any redress, with a thing
I contemn too.
I have read Epictetus twice over against the
Desire of these outward things, and still her face runs in
My mind, I went to say my prayers, and they were
So laid out of the way, that if I could find any prayers I
Had, I am no Christian.
This is the door, and the short
Is, I must see her again. -

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: It is I, I would speak with your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Did she send for you?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No, what then? I would see her, prithee by thy leave.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Not by my leave; for she will not see you, but doth hate you, and
Your friend, and doth wish you both hanged, which being so proper
Men, is great pity, that you are not.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How is this?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
For your sweet self in particular, who she resolves persuaded your
Friend to neglect her, she deemeth whip-cord the most
Convenient unction for your back and shoulders.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Let me in, I will satisfy her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
And if it shall happen that you are in doubt of these my speeches,
Insomuch that you shall spend more time in arguing at the
Door, I am fully persuaded that my Mistress in person from
Above, will utter her mind more at large by way of
Urine upon your head, that it may sink the more soundly
Into your understanding faculties.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
This is the strangest thing, good pretty soul, why dost thou use me so?
I pray thee let me in sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot sweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Thou art a handsome one, and this crossness does become thee.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Alas I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Especially to me; thou knowest when I was here, I said I liked thee of
All thy Mistress servants.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
So did I you, though it be not my fortune to express
It at this present: for truly if you would cry, I cannot
Let you in.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Pox on her, I must go the down-right way: look you
Here is ten pound for you, let me speak with her.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
I like your gold well, but it is a thing by heaven
I cannot do, she
will not speak with you, especially at this time, she has affairs.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
This makes her leave her jesting yet, but take it
And let me see her, bring me to a place
Where undiscerned of herself I may
Feed my desiring eyes but half an hour.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
Why faith I think I can, and I will stretch my wits
And body too for gold: if you will swear as you
Are gentle, not to stir, or speak, where you shall
See or hear, now, or hereafter: give me your gold, I will plant you

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Why, as I am a Gentleman, I will not.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Enough, quick, follow me.
Why where is this maid, she has much care of her business. Nell?
I think she be sunk; - why Nell - whew -

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
I pray you heartily come away, O, come, come, the Gentleman,
My Mistress invited, is coming down the street, and the banquet
Not yet brought out? -

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Nell, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I come forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Now must I walk: when there is any fleshly matters in hand, my
Mistress sends me of a four hours errand: but if I go not
About mine own bodily business as well as she, I am a Turk.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
What, all wide open? It is the way to sin
Doubtless; but I must on; the gates of hell
Are not more passable than these; how they
will be to get out, God knows, I must try.
It is very strange, if there be any life
Within this house, would it would show itself.
What is here? a Banquet? and no mouth to eat,
Or bid me do it? this is something like
The entertainment of adventurous Knights
Entering enchanted Castles: For the manner
Though there be nothing dismal to be seen
Amazes me a little; what is meant
By this strange invitation? I will sound
My Daughters meaning, ere I speak to her,
If it be possible, for by my voice -
She will discover me! hark, whence is this.

Come hither you that love, and hear me sing
of joys still growing
Green, fresh, and lusty, as the pride of Spring,
and ever blowing.
Come hither youths that blush, and dare not know
what is desire,
And old men worse than you, that cannot blow
one spark of fire.
And with the power of my enchanting Song,
Boys shall be able men, and old men young.
Come hither you that hope, and you that cry,
leave off complaining,
Youth, strength, and beauty, that shall never die,
are here remaining.
Come hither fools, and blush, you stay so long
from being blessed,
And mad men worse than you, that suffer wrong,
Yet seek no rest.
And in an hour, with my enchanting Song,
You shall be ever pleased, and young maids long.

div2.stage: Enter Lelia and her maid with a Nightgowne and Slippers.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
Sir you are welcome hither, as this kiss
Given with a larger freedom than the use
Of strangers will admit, shall witness to you.
Put the gown on him, in this chair sit down;
Give him his slippers: be not so amazed,
Here is to your health, and you shall feele this wine
Stir lively in me, in the dead of night.
Give him some wine; fall to your banquet Sir,
And let us grow in mirth; though I am set
Now thus far off you, yet four glasses hence
I will sit here,
And try, till both our bloods
Shoot up and down to find a passage out,
Then mouth, to mouth will we walk up to bed,
And undress one another as we go;
Where both my treasure, body, and my soul
Are yours to be disposed of.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Umh, umh. -

div2.stage: Makes signes of his white head & beard.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
You are old,
Is that your meaning? why, you are to me
The greater novelty, all our fresh youth
Are daily offered me, though you perform
As you think little, yet you satisfy
My appetite: from your experience
I may learn something in the way of lust
I may be better for. But I can teach
These young ones;
But this day I did refuse
A pair of them, Julio, and Angilo,
And told them they were as they were
Raw fools and whelps. a

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Pray God he speak not b

div2.stage: (b Maid lais her finger crosse her mouth to him.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Why speak you not sweet Sir?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Umh. -

div2.stage: (Stops his ears, shews he is troubled with the Musick.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
Peace there, that music, now Sir speak
To me.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Umh. -

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
Why? would you have her gone? you need not keep
Your freedom in for her; she knows my life
That she might write it;
Think she is a stone?
She is a kind of bawdy Confessor,
And will not utter secrets.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Umh. -

div2.stage: Exit Maid. - Fath. locks the doore.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
Be gone then, since he needs will have it so,
It is all one.
Is all now as you would? come meet me then,
And bring a thousand kisses on thy lips,
And I will rob thee of them, and yet leave
Thy lips as wealthy as they were before.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Yes, all is as I would but thou.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: By heaven it is my Father. -

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
And I do beseech thee
Leave these unheard of lusts which worse become thee,
Than mocking of thy Father; let thine eyes
Reflect upon thy soul, and there behold
How loathed black it is; and whereas now
Thy face is heavenly fair, but thy mind foul,
Go but into thy Closet, and there cry
Till thou hast spoiled that face, and thou shalt find
How excellent a change, thou wilt have made
For inward beauty.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
Though I know him now
To be my Father, never let me live
If my lust do abate.
I will take upon me
To have known him all this while.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Look, dost thou know me?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: I knew ye Sir before.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: What didst thou do?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
Knew you, and so unmovedly have you borne
All the sad crosses that I laid upon you,
With such a noble temper, which indeed
I purposely cast on you, to discern
Your carriage in calamity, and you
Have undergone them with that brave contempt,
That I have turned the reverence of a child
Into the hot affection of a Lover.
Nor can there on the earth be found but yours
A spirit fit to meet with mine.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: A woman? thou art not sure.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Look and believe.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
Thou art
Something created to succeed the Devil
When be grows weary of his envious course,
And compassing the world; but I believe thee
Thou didst but mean to try my patience,
And dost so still; but better be advised:
And make thy trial with some other things
That safelier will admit a dalliance:
And if it should be earnest, understand
How cursed thou art, so far from heaven, that thou
Believest it not enough to damn alone,
Or with a stranger, but wouldst heap all sins
Unnatural upon this aged head
And draw thy Father to thy Bed, and hell.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
You are deceived Sir, it is not against nature
For us to lie together; if you have
An arrow of the same tree with your bow,
Is it more unnatural to shoot it there
Than in another? It is our general nature
To procreate, as fires is to consume,
And it will trouble you to find a stick
The fire will turn from: If it be natures will
We should not mix, she will discover to us
Some most apparent crossness, as our organs
will not be fit; which if we do perceive
We will leave, and think it is her pleasure
That we should deal with others

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
The doors are fast; thou shalt not say a prayer,
It is not Gods will thou shouldst; when this is done
I will kill myself, that never man may tell me
I got thee.

div2.stage: Fath. draws his sword. Angilo discovers himself.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: I pray you Sir, help there, for Gods sake Sir.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Hold reverend Sir, for honour of your age.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
For safety of your soul, and of the soul
Of that too wicked woman yet to die.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: What art thou? and how camest thou to that place?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
I am a man so strangely hither come,
That I have broke an oath in speaking this,
But I believe it was better broke than kept,
And I desire your patience; let me in,
And I protest I will not hinder you
In any act you wish, more than by word,
If so I can persuade you, that I will not
Use violence, I willthrow my sword down to you:
This house holds none but I, only a maid
Whom I will lock fast in as I come down.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
I do not know thee, but thy tongue doth seem
To be acquainted with the truth so well
That I will let thee in: throw down thy sword.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: There it is.

div2.stage: He lets in Ang. and lockes the doore.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
How came he there? I am betrayed to shame,
The fear of sudden death struck me all over
So violently, that I scarce have breath
To speak yet: But I have it in my head,
And out it shall, that (Father) may perhaps
Over-reach you yet.

sp.speaker: Fat.
sp.p: Come Sir, what is it you say?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
My Angilo, by all the joys of love
Thou art as welcome as these pliant arms
Twined round, and fast about thee, can persuade thee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
I was in such a fright before thou camest,
Yon old mad fellow, (it will make thee laugh
Though it feared me) has talked so wildly here -
Sirrah, he rushed in at my doors, and swore
He was my Father, and I think believed it:
But that he had a sword, and threatened me -
I'faith he was good sport, good, thrust him out
That thou and I may kiss together; wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
Are you her Champion? and with these fair words,
Got in to rescue her from me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Hold sir,
I swear I do not harbour such a thought,
I speak it not, for that you have two swords,
But for it is truth.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
Two swords my Angilo?
Think this, that thou hast two young brawny arms
And never a sword, and he has two good swords
And never an arm to use them; rush upon him,
I could have beaten him with this weak body,
If I had had the spirit of a man.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Stand from me, and leave talking, or by heaven
I will trample thy last damning word out of thee.

sp.speaker: Fat.
sp.p:
Why do you hinder me then? stand away
And I will rid her quickly.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
Would I were
Clear of this business, yet I cannot pray.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
O be advised, why you were better kill her
If she were good; Convey her from this place
Where none but you, and such as you appoint
May visit her; where let her hear of naught
But death and damning, which she hath deserved,
Till she be truly, justly sorrowful,
And then lay mercy to her, who does know
But she may mend?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: But whither should I bear her?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
To my house,
It is large, and private, I will lend it you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
I thank you Sir, and happily it fits
With some design I have, but how shall we
Convey her?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: will they carry me away?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
For she will scratch and kick, and scream so loud
That people will be drawn to rescue her.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Why? none can hear her here, but her own maid,
Who is as fast as she.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: But in the street?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Why, we will take them both into the Kitchen,
There bind them, and then gag them, and then throw them
Into a Coach I will bring to the backdoor,
And hurry them away.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
It shall be so,
I owe you much for this; and I may pay you,
There is your sword, lay hold upon her quickly,
This way with me, thou disobedient child.
Why does thy stubborn heart beat at thy breast?
Let it be still, for I will have it searched
Till I have found a well of living tears
Within it, that shall spring out of thine eyes,
And flow all over thy body fouled with sin,
Till it have washed it quite without a stain.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
Help! help! ah! ah!
Murther, I shall be murthered, I shall be murthered.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: This helps thee not.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Basely murdered, basely.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: This roguey Captain has made fine work with us.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
I would the Devil in a storm would carry him
Home to his Garrison again; I ache all over,
That I am sure of; Certainly my body
Is of a wild-fire, for my head rings backward,
Or else I have a morise in my brains.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
I will deal no more with soldiers: well remembered,
Did not the Vision promise to appear
About this time again?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
Yes, here he comes:
He is just on his word.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
O, they be here together,
She is penitent, and by my troth I stagger
Whether (as now she is) either of these
Two fools be worthy of her; yet because
Her youth is prone to fall again, ungoverned,
And marriage now may stay her, one of them:
And Piso, since I understand him abler,
Shall be the man; the other bear the charges,
And willingly, as I will handle it.
I have a Ring here, which he shall believe
Is sent him from a woman I have thought of:
But ere I leave it, I will have one of his
In pawn worth two of it: for I will not lose
By such a mess of sugar-sops as this is:
I am too old.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: It moves again, let us meet it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Now if I be not out, we shall have fine sport,
I am glad I have met you Sir, so happily,
You do remember me, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I do Sir.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: This is a short præludium to a challenge.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
I have a message Sir, that much concerns you,
And for your special good; Nay you may hear too.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: What should this fellow mean?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
There is a Lady,
(How the poor thing begins to warm already)
Come to this Town, (as yet a stranger here Sir)
Fair, young, and rich, both in possessions,
And all the graces that make up a woman,
A widow, and a virtuous one: It works,
He needs no broth upon it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What of her Sir?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: No more but this; she loves you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Loves me?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Yes.
And with a strong affection, but a fair one,
If ye be wise and thankful, you are made: there is the whole matter.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I am sure I hear this.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
Here is a Ring Sir, of no little value:
Which after she had seen you at a window,
She bad me haste, and give it, when she blushed
Like a blown rose.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
But pray Sir by your leave -
Methinks your years should promise no ill meaning.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
I am no Bawd, nor cheater, nor a coarser
Of broken-winded women: if you fear me
I will take my leave: and let my Lady use
A fellow of more form; an honester
I am sure she cannot.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Stay, you have confirmed me,
Yet let me feele, you are in health.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
I hope so,
My water is well enough, and my pulse.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Then
All may be excellent: pray pardon me;
For I am like a boy that had found money,
Afraid I dream still.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
Sir, what kind of woman?
Of what proportion is your Lady?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I,

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
I will tell you presently her very picture,
Do you know a woman in this town they call,
Stay, yes, it is so, Lelia?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Not by fight.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Nor you Sir?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: Fa.
Piso.
sp.p:
We have heard though
She is very fair and goodly.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Such another,
Just of the same complexion, making, speech,
But a thought sweeter is my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Then
She must be excellent indeed.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Indeed she is,
And you will find it so; you do believe me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes marry do I, and I am so altered -

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Your happiness will alter any man.
Do not delay the time Sir: at a house
Where Don Valasco lay, the Spanish Seignior
(Which now is Seignior Angelos) she is.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I know it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
But before you show yourself,
Let it be night by all means, willingly
By day she would not have such gallants seen
Repair unto her it is her modesty.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I will go and fit myself.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Do, and be sure
You send provision in, in full abundance,
Fit for the marriage; for this night I know
She will be yours: Sir, have you never a token
Of worth to send her back again? you must,
She will expect it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Yes, pray give her this,
And with it all I have; I am made for ever.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
Well, thou hast fools luck; should I live as long
As an old oak, and say my prayers hourly
I should not be the better of a penny.
I think the Devil be my ghostly Father;
Upon my conscience I am full as handsome,
I am sure I have more wit, and more performance,
Which is a pretty matter.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Do you think sir,
That your friend Seignior Piso will be constant
Unto my Lady? you should know him well.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Who? Seignior Piso?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Yes, the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Why, you are wide Sir.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Is not his name Piso?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: No, mine is Piso.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
It is indeed Sir,
And his is Lodowicke.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Then I am undone Sir,
For I was sent at first to Piso; what a rascal
Was I, so ignorantly to mistake you?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
Peace.
There is no harm done yet.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Now it is too late,
I know my error:
At turning of a Street,
For you were then upon the right hand of him,
You changed your places suddenly: where I
(Like a cross Block-head) lost my memory:
What shall I do? my Lady utterly
will put me from her favour.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
Never fear it,
I will be thy guard, I warrant thee, O, O,
Am I at length reputed? for the Ring,
I will fetch it back with a light vengeance from him:
Had better keep tame Devils, than that Ring;
Art thou not Steward?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Thou shalt be shortly

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Lord how he takes it?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
I will go shift me straight;
Art sure it was to Piso?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: O too sure Sir.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
I will mount thee if I live for it,
Give me patience heaven to be are this blessing I beseech thee;
I am but man; I prithee break my head
To make me understand, I am sensible.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Lend me your dagger, and I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
No
I believe now like a good Christian.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Good Sir make haste; I dare not go without ye
Since I have so mistaken.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
It is no matter,
Meet me within this half hour at St. Margrets.
Well go thy ways old leg, thou hast the trick of it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How now? the news?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Well, passing well, I have them,
Both in a leash and made right for my purpose.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I am glad of it I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Whether man?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: If all go right, I may be fast enough too.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
I cry you mercy Sir, I know your meaning,
Clorais the woman, she is Francks bedfellow,
Commend me to them, and go Julio
Bring them to supper all, to grace this matter;
They serve for witnesses.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.p: I will, Farewell.

div2.stage: Exit Jul at one dore, & Ang, & Fa, at another.
Enter Clora, Franck, and Fredrick, and Maid.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Sister, I brought you Jacamo to the door,
He has forgot all that he said last night:
And shame of that makes him more loath to come,
I left Fabritio persuading him, but it is in vain.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Alas my fortune Clora.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
Now Franck, See what a kind of man you love,
That loves you when he is drunk; If so
Faith I would marry him; My friends I hope
Would make him drink.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
It is well considered Franck, he has such pretty humours then,
Besides being a Soldier, it is better he should love
You when he is drunk, than when he is sober, for then he
will be sure to love you, the greatest part of his life.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: And were not I a happy woman then?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: That ever was born Franck. i'faith -

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How now? what says he?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Faith you may as well tice a dog up with a whip, and bell
As him, by telling him of love and women, he swears
They mock him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Look how my Sister weeps.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Why who can help it?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes, you may safely swear she loves him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Why so I did; and may do all the oaths,
Arithmetic can make, ere he believe me,
And since he was last drunk, he is more jealous
They would abuse him: If we could persuade him
She loved, he would embrace it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
She herself
Shall bate so much of her own modesty
To swear it to him; with such tears as now
You see rain from her.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
I believe it would work,
But would you have her do it in the open street?
Or if you would he will run away from her,
How shall we get him hither?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: By entreaty.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
It is most impossible, No, If we could
Anger him hither, as there is no way
But that to bring him; and then hold him fast
Women, and men, whilst she delivers to him the truth
Sealed with her tears, he would be plain
As a pleased child; he walks below for me
Under the window.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
We will anger him I warrant ye,
Let one of the maids take a good bowl of water,
Or say it be a piss-pot, and pour it on his head.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Content hang me If I like not the cast of it rarely, for no question it,
Is an approved receipt to fetch such a fellow
Take all the women-kind in this house, betwixt the age of one,
And one hundred, and let them take unto them a pot or a
Bowl containing seven quarts or upwards, and let them
Never leave, till the above named,
Pot or Bowl become full, then let one of them stretch out
Her arm and power it on his head, add Probatian est, it
Will fetch him, for in his anger he will run up, and then let
Us alone.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Go you and do it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Good Clora, no.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
Away I say and do it; never fear, we have enough of that
Water ready distilled.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
Why this will make him mad Fabritio,
He will neither love me drunk, nor sober now.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I warrant you: what, is the wench come up?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Art thou there wench?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Look out then if thou canst see him.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p:
Yes I see him, and by my troth he stands so fair I could not
Hold were he my Father; his hat is off too, and he is scratching
His head.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: O wash that hand I prithee.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p:
God send thee good luck, this the second time, I have thrown thee
Out today, ha, ha, ha, just on his head.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Alas!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: What does he now?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: He gathers stones, God's light, he breaks all the Street windows

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Whore's Bawds, your windows, your windows.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p:
Now he is breaking all the low windows with his Sword,
Excellent sport, Now he is beating a fellow that laughed at him;
Truly the man takes it patiently; Now he goes down the Street
Gravely, looking on each side, there is not one more dare laugh.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Does he go on?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
Fabritio, you have undone a Maid
By treachery; know you some other better,
You would prefer your friend to? If you do not
Bring him again, I have no other hope,
But you that made me lose hope, If you fail me,
I never shall see him, but shall languish out
A discontented life, and die contemned.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
This vexes me, I pray you be more patient
If I have any truth, let what will happen,
I will bring him presently, Do you all stand
At the Street door, the Maids, and all, to watch
When I come back, and have some private place
To shuffle me into, for he shall follow
In fury, but I know I can out run him:
As he comes in, clap all fast hold on him,
And use your own discretions.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: We will do it.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
But suddenly for I will bring him hither,
With that unstopped speed that you shall run over
All that is in his way: and though my life be ventured
It is no great matter, will do it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
I thank you,
Worthy Fabritio.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
I ever knew no woman could abide me,
But am I grown so contemptible, by being once drunk
Amongst them, that they begin to throw piss on my head?
For surely it was piss huh, huh.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Jacomo, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Well, something troubled with waterish humours.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Foh, how thou stinkest; prithee stand further of me
Methinks these humours become thee better than thy dry
Choleric humours, or thy wine-wet humours; ha?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
You are pleasant, but Fabrito know I am not in the wood of
Suffering jest.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
If you be not in the mood I hope you will not be moody
But truly I cannot blame the Gentlewoman, you stood eavesdropping,
Under their window, and would not come up.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Sir, I suspect now, by your idle talk
Your hand was in it, which if I once believe,
Be sure you shall account to me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
The Gentlewomen and the Maids have counted to you already
The next turn I see is mine.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Let me die but this is very strange; good Fabritio
Do not provoke me so.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Provoke you? you are grown the strongest fellow; there is no
Keeping company with you, phish; take you that.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O all the Devils? stand Slave.

div2.stage: Fab. gives him a box o'th ear sodainly, &c throws him from him, &c goes his waie, whilst Iaca. drawes his Sword.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: follow me if thou darest.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Stay coward, stay. -

div2.stage: Enter Fred. Fra. Clora. and Servant and Maid

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
Be ready for I see Fabritio running,
And Jacamo behind him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Where is the place.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That way Fabritio.

div2.stage: (Fred. Clor, and Maid, lay hold on Jacamo.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Where art thou treacher?
What is the matter Sirs?
Why do you hold me? I am basely wronged,
Torture, and hell, be with you; let me go.

div2.stage: (they drag him to a chaire and hold him downe in't.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Good Iacamo be patient, and but hear
What I can say, you know I am your friend,
If you yet doubt it, by my soul I am.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
'sdeath stand away;
I would my breath were poison.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
As I have life that which was thrown on you,
And this now done, were but to draw you hither
For causes weighty, that concern yourself
Void of all malice, which this Maid my Sister
Shall tell you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Puh, a pox upon you all; you will not hold me
For ever here, and till you let me go,
I will talk no more.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p:
As you are a Gentleman
Let not this boldness make me be believed,
To be immodest; If there were a way
More silently to be acquainted with you
God knows, that I would choose, But as it is
Take it in plainness: I do love you more
Than you do your content, If you refuse
To pity me, I will never cease to weep,
And when mine eyes be out I will be told
How fast the tears I shed for you do fall,
And if they do not flow abundantly,
I will fetch a sigh shall make them start, and leap,
As if the fire wear under.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Fine mocking, fine mocking.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Mocking? look how she weeps.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Does she counterfeit crying too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Behold how the tears flow, or pity her
Or never more be called a man.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
How is this? soft you, soft you my Masters: Is it possible think you,
She should be in earnest?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
Earnest? Aye in earnest: she is a fool to break so many sleeps,
That would have been sound ones, and venture such a face, and
So much life, for ever an humorous ass in the world.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
Why Clora? I have known you cry as much?
For Julio, that has not half his worth,
All night you write and weep too much I fear
I do but what I should.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
If I do write
I am answered Franck.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I would I might be so.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Good Fredrick let me go I would fain try
If that thing do not counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Give me your Sword then.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
No, but take my word,
As I am man, I will not hurt a creature
Under this roof, before I have delivered
Myself, as I am now into your hands,
Or have your full consent.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: It is enough.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
Gentlewoman, I pray you let me feel your face; I am an
Infidel, if she do not weep. Stay, where is my handkerchief?
I will wipe the old wert off, the fresh tears come, pox on it
I am a handsome, gracious fellow amongst women, and
Knew it not Gentlewoman; how should I know these tears are
For me? Is not your Mother dead?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: By heaven they are for you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Slight I will have my head cooled, and powdered tomorrow
By break of day; If you love me, I pray you kiss me,
For If I love you, it shall be such love, as I will not be
A shamed of, If this be a mock -
It is the heartiest, and the sweetest mock
That ever I tasted, mock me so again -

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Fie Iacamo? why do you let her kneel
So long?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
It is true I had forgot it
And should have done this twelvemonth; pray you rise
Fredrick, If I could all this while have been persuaded she could
Have loved me, dost thou think I had not rather kiss her
Than another should? and yet you may gull me for ought
I know, but if you do, hell take me If I do not cut
All your throats sleeping.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: O do not think of such a thing.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Otherwise, If she be in earnest, the short is I am.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Alas, I am.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
And I did not think it possible any woman
Could have liked this face, it is good for nothing, is it?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
Yes it is worth forty shillings to pawn, being lined almost quite
Through with velvet.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: It is better than your Iulio's.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Thou thinkest so,
But otherwise, in faith it is not Franck -

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Hist Iacamo; How dost thou Boy? ha?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Why very well, I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Dost thou perceive the reason of matters, and passages,
Yet Sirrah, or no?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: It is wondrous good Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
I have done simply for you, but now you are beaten to some
Understanding, I pray you dally not with the Gentlewoman
But dispatch your Matrimony, with all convenient speed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: He gives good counsel.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: And I will follow it.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
And I you, prithee do not take it unkindly,
For trust me I boxed thee for thy advancement,
A foolish desire I had to joggle thee into preferment.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
I apprehend you Sir, and if I can study out a course
How a bastinadoing may any ways raise your fortunes
In the State, you shall be sure of it.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: O Sir keep your way, God send you much joy.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p:
And me my Iulio.
O God I hear his voice, now he is true,
Have at a marriage Franck, as soon as you -

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Sir I would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What is your hasty business friend?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: The Duke commands your present attendance at Court.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The cause?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
I know not in particular; but this
Many are sent for more, about affairs
Foreign I take it Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
I will be there
Within this hour, return my humble service.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Farewell friend, what news is with you?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
My Mistress would desire you Sir to follow
With all the haste you can, she is gon to Church,
To marry Captain Iacamo, and Iulio,
To do as much for the young merry Gentlewoman,
Fair Mistress Clora.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Julio, marry Clora?
Thou art deceived I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
No sure Sir,
I saw their lips as close upon the bargain.
As Cockles.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Give them joy, I cannot now go,
The Duke hath sent for me in haste.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: This note Sir: when you are free, will bring you where they are.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
You shall find us all at Seignior Angilo's,
Where Piso, and the worthy Lelia
Of famous memory are to be married,
And we not far behind.
Would I had time
To wonder at this last couple in hell.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: You are staid for Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
I come, pray God the business
Hold me not from this sport, I would not lose it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
God give you joy, and make you live together
A happy pair.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
I do not doubt we shall.
There was never poor Gentleman had such a sudden fortune,
I could thrust my head betwixt two pales, and strip me out of
My old skin like a Snake: will the guests come thou saidst
Thou sentest for to solemnise the Nuptials?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: They will, I look for them ere this.

div2.stage: Enter Julio, Jacamo, Fabritio, Franke, Clora.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: By your leave all.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: They are here Sir.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
Especially fair Lady
I ask your pardon, to whose marriage bed
I wish all good success, I have here brought you
Such guests as can discern your happiness,
And best do know how to rejoice at it;
For such a fortune they themselves have run,
The worthy Iacamo, and his fair Bride,
Noble Fabritio, whom this age of peace
Has not yet aught to love ought but the wars,
And his true friends, this Lady who is but
A piece of me.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
Sir, you are welcome all,
Are they not Sir?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
Bring in some wine, some of the wine Lodwick the fool.
Sent hither: whoever thou biddest welcome shall find it

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
An unexpected honour you have done
To our too hasty wedding.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Faith Madam, our weddings were as hasty as yours
WE&Htp; are glad to run up and down any whether, to see where
We can get meat to our wedding.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: That Lodwick hath provided too, good Ass.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
I thought you Iulio, would not thus have stolen a marriage
Without acquainting your friends.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Why I did give thee incklings.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
If a marriage should be thus slubbend up in a play, ever almost
Anybody had taken notice you were in love, the Spectators
Would take it to be but ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
This was the first, and I will never hide
An other secret from you.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p:
Sir, yonder is your friend Lodwick, hide yourself
And it will be the best sport -

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, I pray you take no notice, I am here.
The coxcomb Lodwick is coming in.

sp.speaker: Lodwick.
sp.p: Is that that Lady?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: That is my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: As I live she is a fair one; what make all these here?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: O Lord Sir she is so pestered -

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Now will the sport be, it runnes right as Iulio told us

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Fair Lady health to you; some words I have, that
Require an utterance more private,
Than this place can afford.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
I will call my husband
All business I hear with his ears now.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Good Madam no, bet I perceive your jest,
You have no husband, I am the very man
That walked the streets so comely.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Are you so?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Yes faith, when Cupid first did prick your heart
I am not cruel, but the love began
In the Street I will satisfy in the chamber fully.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
To ask a Madman whether he be mad
Were but an idle question, if you be,
I do not speak to you, but if you be not
Walk in the Streets again and there perhaps
I may dote on you, here I not endure you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Good Madam stay, do not you know this Ring?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
Yes it was mine, I sent it by my Man,
To change and so he did, it has a blemish,
And this he brought me for it; did you change it?
Are you a Goldsmith?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Sure the world is mad,
Sirrah, did you not bring me this ring from your Lady?

sp.speaker: Fa.
Lod.
sp.p: Married? to whom?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: To your worships friend Piso.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'sdeath to Piso?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Yes Sir I can assure you she is married to him, I saw it
With these gray eyes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Why what a Rogue art thou then? thou hast made in his mouth
Me send in provision too.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
O a Gentleman should not have such foul words in his mouth
But your Worships provision could not have come in at a fitter time;
will it please you to taste any of your own wine?
it may be the Vintner has cozened you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Pox I am mad.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You have always plots Sir, and see how they fall out.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: You had a plot upon me, how do you like this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I do not speak to you.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Because you dare not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: But I will have one of that old Rogues teeth set in this Ring

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
Dost not thou know that I can beat thee?
Dost thou know it now? (discovers himself)

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: He beat me once indeed.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
And if you have forgot it, I can call a witness.
Come forth Piso - remember you it?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Faith I do call to mind such a matter.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
And if I cannot still do it, you are young
And will assist your Father in law.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: My Father in law?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Your Father in law, as sure as this is widow Lelia.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: How widow Lelia?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: I'faith it is she, Son.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, let my provision go, I am glad I
Have missed the woman.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Have you put a whore upon me?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
By heaven you do me wrong, I have a heart
As pure as any woman's, and I mean
To keep it so for ever.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
There is no starting now, Son, if you offer it
I can compel you, her estate is great,
But all made over to me, before this match,
Yet if you use her kindly, as I swear
I think she will deserve, you shall enjoy it
During your life, all save some slender piece
I will reserve for my own maintenance,
And if God bless you with a child by her,
It shall have all.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p:
So I may have the means
I do not much care what the woman is:
Come my sweet heart, as long as I shall find
Thy kisses sweet, and thy means plentiful,
Let people talk their tongues out.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p:
They may talk
Of what is past, but all that is to come
Shall be without occasions.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Shall we not make Piso, and Lodwick friends?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p:
Hang them they dare not be Enemies, or if they be,
The danger is not great, welcome Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fredrick.
sp.p:
First joy unto you all; and next I think
We shall have wars.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Give me some wine, I will drink to that.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I will pledge.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But I shall lose you then.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Not a whit wench; I will teach thee presently to be a Soldier

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Fabritios command, and yours are both restored

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Bring me four glasses then.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
You shall not drink them here, it is supper time,
And from my house no creature here shall stir,
These three days, mirth shall flow as well as wine.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Content, within I will tell you more at large
How much I am bound to all, but most to you,
Whose undeserved liberality
Must not escape thus unrequited.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
It is happiness to me, I did so well:
Of every noble action, the intent
Is to give worth reward, vice, punishment.
